awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Hybrid additive manufacturing that provides computational solutions to fabricate geometrically complex components
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a software platform that provides hybrid manufacturing solutions for designing light-weight mechanical systems with predictable short- and long-term failure rates. Providing a targeted hybrid manufacturing solution may extend service life and reduce operational costs by improving strength and production quality. As a result, additive manufacturing becomes accessible to aerospace and biomedical applications that have strict functional design and reliability requirements or geometrically complex structures. Geometric complexity and lattice structures are becoming a staple in modern design. Current tools such as topology optimization are incapable of maximizing strength-to-weight ratios. This software platform provides a hybrid manufacturing solution that optimizes weight while it proactively increases strength through interlayer cold working. In aerospace components, this lowers the buy-to-fly ratio by saving weight, which lowers fuel cost. In addition, this software platform addresses maintenance and reliability issues of legacy aircraft and tool-and-die components by significantly reducing lead times for replacement parts with enhanced aftermarket performance. The technology may provide industry with software solutions to best manufacture components requiring weight savings or known times to failure.  

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a hybrid additive manufacturing technology that combines three-dimensional printing with secondary material strengthening processes, such as laser peening, to improve functional performance. Laser peening is a surface treatment that induces favorable compressive residual stress in components to increase hardness and strength throughout large build volumes. The technical barrier addressed by this technology is understanding when, where, and how much laser peening is needed throughout the build volume. The proposed technology provides computational solutions for hybrid additive manufacturing that identify optimal locations for interlayer peening needed to achieve the highest possible strength-to-weight ratios without compromising functionality or performance. The model is able to simulate distortion and strength from cumulative residual stress fields induced by interlayer peening. This technology has been shown to increase toughness of stainless steel by 50% and increase corrosion resistance of a biomedical-grade magnesium alloy by 70% compared to traditional additive manufacturing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This NSF I-Corps project focused on advancing and commercializing hybrid additive manufacturing (hybrid AM), a cutting-edge technology that combines 3D printing with inter-layer laser peening to improve the performance of metal components. The project addressed key challenges in additive manufacturing, such as inconsistent quality, limited mechanical durability, and high production costs, with significant benefits for industries such as aerospace, defense, and healthcare.

Over the course of the award, the project achieved several notable milestones. The team developed and patented methodologies to enhance material properties using hybrid AM, enabling the production of high-performance components with superior quality and reliability. This work led to the development of innovative manufacturing solutions that contributed to the creation of startups focused on aerospace and medical applications. Prototypes were produced with advanced features, including lightweight magnesium parts with near-zero porosity to support the production of legacy aircraft components for the military, as well as optimized surgical tools that enhance patient care and improve surgical outcomes. Through extensive customer discovery efforts, the team validated commercialization opportunities and secured strong partnerships with key industry stakeholders. Additionally, hybrid AM demonstrated reductions in production times and costs, making it a viable solution for industrial-scale applications.

The project made notable contributions to the field of advanced manufacturing by developing and validating the HybridSIM™ software, a computational tool designed to optimize the laser peening process during additive manufacturing. This tool improves mechanical and corrosion properties in printed parts by simulating and refining processing parameters. By enhancing material strength and durability, HybridSIM™ enables the production of high-performance components suitable for demanding environments, including aerospace applications and medical devices. These findings enrich the knowledge base in additive manufacturing by providing new insights into integrating computational modeling with physical manufacturing processes.

The project also provided invaluable training and mentorship for students, equipping them with skills in advanced manufacturing, computational modeling, and entrepreneurship. Participants gained hands-on experience in patent development, interdisciplinary collaboration, and technology commercialization, preparing them to contribute to future innovations in engineering and science.

This project established a foundation for the widespread adoption of hybrid AM technologies, demonstrating their potential to revolutionize manufacturing across diverse industries. By bridging the gap between academic research and industrial applications, this work has positioned hybrid AM as a transformative solution for creating sustainable, high-performance components that address critical societal and industrial needs.


Last Modified: 11/19/2024
Modified by: Michael P Sealy
